S. Barnes & Company, Barnes Tantivy Press |isbn=978-0-498-02395-8}} (a memoir by the maitre d' of the club during its final years). * Beebe, Lucius. ''The Stork Club Bar Book''. New York: Rinehart & Company, 1946. * Brooks, Johnny. "My Life Behind Bars". (Note: Brooks was a bartender of the Stork Club.) * ''The Stork Club Cookbook''. New York: The Stork Club, Inc., 1949 (later reprinted in paperback). * Caspary, Vera. ''The Murder in the Stork Club'' (novel). New York: Walter J. Black, 1946. ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.storkclub.com}} * [http://spoonercentral.com/sylvanspoon/storkpics.html Inside the Cub Room at the Stork Club] * [http://life.time.com/curiosities/nightclub-hand-signals-a-primer-from-new-yorks-legendary-stork-club/ Alfred Eisenstaedt's 1944 Stork Club photos for LIFE magazine] * {{Find a Grave|5097|Sherman Billingsley}} * [http://www.jitterbuzz.com/menus.html Memorabilia, Photos and Downloadable Menu from the Stork Club] [[Category:1929 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:1965 disestablishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct drinking establishments in Manhattan]] [[Category:Defunct restaurants in New York City]] [[Category:Midtown Manhattan]] [[Category:New York City nightlife]] [[Category:Nightclubs in Manhattan]] [[Category:Restaurants established in 1929]] [[Category:Speakeasies]]

[[File:Convoi Exceptionnel.jpg|thumb|Convoi Exceptionnel by the Dutch company: [[Close-Act Theatre]]]] [[Image:Streetperformers.jpg|thumb|right|A troupe of street theatre performers by the beach in [[Vancouver]], British Columbia, Canada]] [[Image:Mischief makers 04.jpg|thumb|right|[[Nottingham]]-based arts activist collective [[The Mischief Makers]] use the street for their performances.]] [[File:Salvador, La Marioneta Gigante.jpg|thumb|Acrobatics over Salvador: ''La Marioneta Gigante'' by Spanish company [[Carros de foc]]]]
'''Street theatre''' is a form of [[theatre|theatrical]] [[performance]] and presentation in outdoor [[public space]]s without a specific paying audience. These spaces can be anywhere, including [[Shopping mall|shopping centres]], [[Parking lot|car parks]], recreational reserves, college or university campus and street corners. They are especially seen in outdoor spaces where there are large numbers of people. The actors who perform street theatre range from [[busking|busker]]s to organised theatre companies or groups that want to experiment with performance spaces, or to promote their mainstream work. It was a source of providing information to people when there were no sources of providing information like television, radio etc. Nowadays, street play is used to convey a message to the crowd watching it.<ref>https://www.youthkiawaaz.com/2011/08/street-plays-a-means-of-spreading-awareness/</ref> Street play is considered to be the rawest form of acting, because one does not have a microphone or loud speakers.{{cn|date=September 2018}}
Sometimes performers are commissioned, especially for street [[festival]]s, children's shows or [[parade]]s, but more often street theatre performers are unpaid or gather some income through the dropping of a coin in a hat by the audience.
The logistics of doing street theatre necessitate simple [[costume]]s and [[Theatrical property|prop]]s, and often there is little or no [[Electronic amplifier|amplification]] of sound, with actors depending on their natural [[human voice|vocal]] and physical ability. This issue with sound has meant that [[physical theatre]], including dance, [[mime artist|mime]] and [[slapstick]], is a very popular genre in an outdoor setting. The performances need to be highly visible, loud and simple to follow in order to attract a crowd.
Street theatre should be distinguished from other more formal outdoor theatrical performances, such as performances in a park or garden, where there is a discrete space set aside (or [[rope]]d off) and a [[Ticket (admission)|ticketed]] audience.
In some cases, street theatre performers have to get a [[licence]] or specific permission through [[local government|local]] or [[State (subnational)|state]] [[government]]s in order to perform. Many performers travel internationally<ref>[http://performers.net/ International list of performers]</ref> to certain locations of note.
Street theatre is arguably the oldest form of theatre in existence: most mainstream entertainment mediums can be traced back to origins in street performing, including religious [[passion plays]] and many other forms. More recently performers who, a hundred years ago, would have made their living working in [[variety theatre]]s, [[music hall]]s and in [[vaudeville]], now often perform professionally in the many well-known street performance areas throughout the world. Notable performers that began their careers as street theatre performers include [[Robin Williams]],<ref>Robin Williams began his career on the streets of San Francisco as a street performer: https://movies.yahoo.com/movie/contributor/1800013042/bio</ref> [[David Bowie]], [[Jewel (singer)|Jewel]] and [[Harry Anderson]].
Street theatre allows people who might not have ever been to, or been able to afford to go to, traditional theatre. The audience is made up of anyone and everyone who wants to watch and for most performances is free entertainment.
==Reasons for staging work on the street==
Performance artists with an interest in social activism may choose to stage their work on the street as a means of directly confronting or engaging the public. For example, multimedia artist Caeser Pink and his group of performers known as The Imperial Orgy staged a piece titled ''Our Daily Bread''<ref>[https://archive.org/details/CaeserPinkOurDailyBread-OrgyStreetTheateronWallStreet Archive Video]</ref> that brought performers onto the streets of the New York's financial district to ceremoniously lay loaves of [[Wonder Bread]] along the sidewalks, each with an advertisement from Satan offering to buy people's souls in exchange for material possessions. The performance caused an uproar when police were called out and bomb-sniffing dogs were brought in to inspect the loaves of bread for explosives.
Other artists consider a paying, theatre-going public to be unrepresentative of the public to whom they are trying to communicate, and performing to 'the man on the street' may be considered a more democratic form of dissemination.
Some contemporary street theatre practitioners have extensively studied pre-existing street and popular theatre traditions, such as [[Carnival]], [[commedia dell'arte]] etc. and wish to present them in a situation close to their original context.
Whatever the reason for choosing the street, the street is a place with a different set of possibilities than the conventional theatre space. Sue Gill of [[Welfare State International]] argues that a street theatre performance is not a lesser form than an indoor performance, nor is it simply taking what you do on stage and placing it outdoors, but a form with an energy and an integrity of its own.<ref>{{Cite book | editor-last = Coult | editor-first = Tony | editor2-last = Kershaw | editor2-first = Baz | title = Engineers of the Imagination: The Welfare State Handbook | publisher = Methuen | year = 1983 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=oPkCAAAAMAAJ&q=engineers+of+the+imagination&dq=engineers+of+the+imagination&pgis=1 | isbn = 0-413-52800-6}}</ref>
[[File:PSI India street play.jpg|thumb|left|180px|A street play (''nukkad natak'') in [[Dharavi]] slums in Mumbai]]. Many companies are politically motivated and use street theatre to combine performance with protest. This has occurred through the [[guerrilla theatre]] of [[San Francisco Mime Troupe]],<ref>{{Cite book| last = Doyle | first = Michael William | title = Imagine Nation: The American Counterculture of the '60s and '70s | publisher = Routeledge | year = 2001 | url = http://www.diggers.org/guerrilla_theater.htm | isbn = 0-415-93040-5}}</ref> [[The Living Theatre]], the carnivalesque parades of [[Bread and Puppet Theatre]], and the work of [[Ashesh Malla]] and the Sarwanam Theatre Group of [[Nepal]].
A character-based street theatre which developed in the 1960s and 1970s was developed by groups like Lumiere and Son, John Bull Puncture Repair Kit, Exploded Eye and Natural Theatre Company. The performances were unannounced and featured characters who acted out a pre-arranged scenario, looking beautiful or surreal or simply just involving passers by in conversation. They did not seek to trick in a ''[[Candid Camera]]'' way, but rather invited the audience to pretend along with them. No amount of planning or rehearsal could dictate what would happen.
Another example would be Natural Theatre's Pink Suitcase scenario. A number of smartly dressed people carrying bright pink suitcases enter a set of streets or buildings. They search for and miss their companions. In their search they get on buses, hail cabs, end up in shop windows, etc. By the time they meet up at a pre-arranged spot with the help of passers-by, perceptions of the area have changed and shopping has ceased for at least a few moments. The humour is universal and this piece has been seen in nearly seventy countries. It is usually performed by four or five actors, but has been done with twenty-five.
==See also== {{div col}} * [[Carros de foc]] * [[Close-Act Theatre]] * [[Freak show]] * [[Medicine show]] * [[One-Mensch-Theater]] * [[Royal de luxe]] * [[Sideshow]] * [[Street musician]] {{div col end}}
==Notes== {{reflist}}
== Further reading == * {{citation |first= Patricia J. |last= Campbell |title= Passing the hat: Street performers in America |year= 1981 |location= New York |publisher= Delacorte Press |isbn= 978-0-385-28773-9 |oclc= 7461199 }} — Discusses buskers in a number of cities, focusing on their reasons for street performing; the dedication, skill, and discipline required to develop an act; and unpleasantries with hasslers and the law. * {{citation |author1= Gazzo |first2= Danny |last2= Hustle |first3= James E |last3= Wells |title= The Art of Krowd Keeping |publisher= Penguin Magic |year= 2006 |oclc= 211995463 |url= http://www.penguinmagic.com/p/1158 }} * {{citation |first= Floriane |last= Gaber |title= 40 Years of Street Arts |publisher= Ici et là |year= 2009 |location= Paris |isbn= 978-2-9533890-8-1 |oclc= 741522717 }} * {{citation |first= Floriane |last= Gaber |title= Comment ça commença: les arts de la rue dans le contexte des années 70 |trans-title=How It All Started. Street arts in the context of the 1970s |publisher= Ici et là |year= 2009 |location= Paris |language= French |isbn= 978-2-9533890-4-3 |oclc= 650908877 }}
== External links == {{Commons category|Street theatre}} * [https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&id=vyPfW6FLB1IC&dq=street+theatre&printsec=frontcover&source=web&ots=Q3AgvIUKrW&sig=XxmdRejCb64q3GVnDdx1TFHRuXs&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=3&ct=result#PPP8,M1 Street Theatre and Other Outdoor Performance] Online Book (preview only) Street Theatre and Other Outdoor Performance By Bim Mason Published by Routledge, 1992 {{ISBN|0-415-07050-3}}, {{ISBN|978-0-415-07050-8}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Street Theatre}} [[Category:Street performance]] [[Category:Entertainment]] [[Category:Performance art]] [[Category:Street theatre|*]]

{{Userspace draft|source=ArticleWizard|date=November 2017}} {{Infobox video game | collapsible = | title = Three Dirty Dwarves | image = | alt = | caption = | developer = [[Appaloosa Interactive]] | publisher = [[Sega]] | engine = | platforms = [[Sega Saturn]], PC | released = 1996 | genre = [[Beat 'em up]] | modes = [[Single player]], [[multiplayer]] | director = László Szenttornyai | producer = | designer = | programmer = | artist = | writer = | composer = }} '''''Three Dirty Dwarves''''' is a 1996 [[beat 'em up]] [[video game]] developed by [[Appaloosa Interactive]] and published by [[Sega]] for their [[Sega Saturn]] console. It was later ported to PC.
Even before its release on the Saturn, SegaSoft announced that ''Three Dirty Dwarves'' would be the first game they would publish for the [[PlayStation (console)|PlayStation]] once they acquired a PlayStation software license.<ref>{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=Sega Soft Plans PlayStation Titles|magazine=[[GamePro]]|issue=95|publisher=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|date=August 1996|page=16}}</ref> However, SegaSoft ended up never publishing any games for the PlayStation.
==Gameplay== Most levels in ''Three Dirty Dwarves'' play in a typical beat 'em up format: players must advance the characters to the end of the stage, defeating any enemies which block the way. Up to three players take control of the three titular dwarves, with each player controlling one dwarf at a time; if there are fewer than three players, the player(s) can change which dwarf they are controlling at any time. A single hit from an enemy or obstacle will render a dwarf unconscious, but if another dwarf is still in action he can revive an unconscious dwarf by attacking him, effectively slapping him awake.<ref name="GPro98"/>
Each dwarf has a short-range attack and a long-range attack, though the speed and responsiveness of each attack varies according to the dwarf. In addition, the dwarves can spend skulls to activate special team attacks, such as starting a fight with each other or morphing into one of three huge gestalt dwarves. Skull are acquired by picking them up from fallen enemies or breaking open boxes.<ref name="EGM87"/>
==Story== Four children genetically engineered by the army grow up to be child geniuses instead of perfect soldiers, prompting General Briggs to use them to manufacture weaponry.<ref name="EGM87">{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=Three Dirty Dwarves: They're Makeshift Sportsmen and, Man, Do they Stink|magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]|issue=87 |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=October 1996|pages=128-9}}</ref>
To escape, the children play their favorite [[role-playing game]] and lead the party - a trio of slow-witted but heroic dwarves - to a gateway into the real world. The dwarves' equipment burns up during [[atmospheric entry]]. They land in a [[sporting goods store]] and make use of the equipment inside for their weapons and armor. The monsters from the role-playing game world have followed the dwarves into the real world, and the dwarves must battle their way through them to find the children and confront General Briggs.<ref name="EGM87"/>
After the dwarves defeat Briggs' subordinate Barney and get past the army bases' automated defenses, Briggs offers them jobs in the army with generous benefits. The dwarves are on the verge of taking the offer, so the children roll the die for their role-playing game until the right number comes up, forcing the dwarves to turn down Briggs' offer and insist on the children's release. Briggs complies, but the dwarves proceed to beat him up anyway. The children use the distraction to sneak off of the base to freedom.
==Reception== {{Video game reviews | EGM = 7.5/10 (SAT)<ref name="EGM87rev">{{cite magazine|magazine=[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]] |title=Review Crew: Three Dirty Dwarves |publisher=[[Ziff Davis]] |date=October 1996 |issue=87 |page=61}}</ref> | rev1 = ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]'' | rev1Score = {{rating|3|5}} (SAT)<ref name="NGen23">{{cite magazine|last=|first= |title=Three Dirty Dwarves|magazine=[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]] |issue=23|publisher=[[Imagine Media]]|date=November 1996 |pages=272, 275}}</ref> | rev2 = ''[[Sega Saturn Magazine]]'' | rev2Score = 65% (SAT)<ref name="SatMag15">{{cite magazine|last=Allsetter |first=Rob |title=Review: 3 Dirty Dwarves|magazine=[[Sega Saturn Magazine]]|issue=14|publisher=[[Emap International Limited]]|date=December 1996|pages=78-79}}</ref> }} The Sega Saturn version received moderately positive reviews, with most critics praising the game's humor and personality.<ref name="EGM87rev"/><ref name="NGen23"/><ref name="GPro98">{{cite magazine|last= |first= |title=ProReview: Three Dirty Dwarves |magazine=[[GamePro]]|issue=98 |publisher=[[International Data Group|IDG]]|date=November 1996 |page=124}}</ref> The four reviewers of ''[[Electronic Gaming Monthly]]'' especially praised the comic weirdness of the cutscenes and the general fun of the game.<ref name="EGM87rev"/> A ''[[Next Generation (magazine)|Next Generation]]'' critic remarked that the side-scrolling beat 'em up genre was becoming tried, but that ''Three Dirty Dwarves'', while not genuinely innovative, "offers just enough new spins on the tradition to make it a worthwhile venture." He found the varied and often surprising levels and the consistently solid challenge to be key.<ref name="NGen23"/> Major Mike of ''[[GamePro]]'' said the jumping and three-dimensional gameplay can be awkward, but aspects such as the three-player mode and humor "make this game something special."<ref name="GPro98"/> Rob Allsetter of ''[[Sega Saturn Magazine]]'' gave ''Three Dirty Dwarves'' one of its few negative reviews, calling it "a very irritating and mundane platform game". He lambasted the game's humor and said the gameplay is repetitive.<ref name="SatMag15"/>
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{infobox Organization |name = Unión de Radioaficionados Españoles |image = URE_logo.png |image_border = |size = 68px |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = URE |motto = |formation = |extinction = |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |status = |purpose = Advocacy, Education |headquarters = |location = [[Madrid]], [[Spain]]
{{Coor Maidenhead|40.390611|-3.670914|yes}} |region_served = [[Spain]] |membership = 8,000 |language = [[Spanish language|Spanish]] |leader_title = President |leader_name = Enrique Herrera EA5AD |main_organ = |affiliations = [[International Amateur Radio Union]] |num_staff = |budget = |website = http://www.ure.es/ |remarks = }} The '''Unión de Radioaficionados Españoles''' ('''URE''') (in [[English language|English]], '''Spanish Amateur Radio Union''') is a national [[non-profit organization]] for [[amateur radio]] enthusiasts in [[Spain]]. The organization has approximately 12,000 members, predominantly [[amateur radio operators]] in Spain. URE promotes amateur radio by sponsoring [[amateur radio operating award]]s and radio [[contesting|contests]]. The URE also represents the interests of Spanish amateur radio operators and [[shortwave listening|shortwave listeners]] before Spanish and international telecommunications regulatory authorities.Unión de Radioaficionados Españoles (2008). [http://www.ure.es/ "Bienvenidos a la Web de URE"]. Retrieved Aug. 5, 2008. URE is the national member society representing Spain in the [[International Amateur Radio Union]].International Amateur Radio Union (2008). [http://www.iaru.org/iaru-soc.html "Member Societies"]. Retrieved Aug. 1, 2008. == See also == *[[International Amateur Radio Union]] == References == {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Union de Radioaficionados Espanoles}} [[Category:International Amateur Radio Union member societies|Spain]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Spain]] [[Category:Radio in Spain]] [[Category:Organisations based in Madrid]] {{Spain-org-stub}} {{Amateur-radio-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox broadcasting network | network_name = (ZBC) {{en icon}}| network_logo = [[File:Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (logo).jpg|150px|Logo of the ZBC]] | country = [[Zimbabwe]] | network_type = [[Television network]]
[[Radio network]] | available = National
Worldwide | owner = [[Government of Zimbabwe]] | launch_date = 1963 (as Rhodesian Broadcasting Corporation) | past_names = Rhodesian Broadcasting Corporation, and later
Zimbabwe Rhodesian Broadcasting Corporation | website = http://www.zbc.co.zw }} The '''Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation '''('''ZBC''') is the state-controlled broadcaster in [[Zimbabwe]]. It was established as the '''Rhodesian Broadcasting Corporation''' ('''RBC'''), taking its current name in 1980. Like the RBC before it, the ZBC has been accused of being a [[government mouthpiece]] with no [[editorial independence]].[http://www.theindependent.co.zw/2012/02/16/muckraker-zbc-has-taken-over-the-rbcs-mantle/ 'MuckRaker: ZBC has taken over the RBC's mantle'], ''[[Zimbabwe Independent]]'', 16 February 2012 ==History== ===Introduction of radio=== Radio was first introduced in the then [[Southern Rhodesia]] in 1933, in Belvedere in Salisbury (now [[Harare]]) by [[Imperial Airways]], which was used to provide radio guidance and weather reports.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZgptYdAcsOgC&lpg=PA159&dq=zbc%20radio%204&pg=PA159#v=onepage&q&f=false ''World Broadcasting: A Comparative View''], Alan Wells, Greenwood Publishing Group, 1996, pages 157-159 However, it was not until 1941 that the first professional broadcaster was established.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=LJbFniZhtDQC&lpg=PA10&dq=%22Southern%20Rhodesia%22%20%22radio%22%201933&pg=PA10#v=onepage&q=%22Southern%20Rhodesia%22%20%22radio%22%201933&f=false ''Zimbabwe: A Survey''], African Minds, 2009, page 10 This was known as the Central African Broadcasting Service (CABS) and had responsibility for broadcasting in [[Northern Rhodesia]] (now [[Zambia]]) and [[Nyasaland]] (now [[Malawi]]) as well as Southern Rhodesia. Following the creation of the [[Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland]] in 1953, a new organisation was established on 1 February 1958, known as the Federal Broadcasting Corporation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland (FBC).[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=DnFHAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22Federal+Broadcasting+Corporation+of+Rhodesia+and+Nyasaland%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Federal+Broadcasting+Corporation%22 ''Handbook to the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland''], Rhodesia and Nyasaland, Federal Information Dept, William Vernon Brelsford, Cassell, 1960, page 552 However, CABS continued to operate as a radio station aimed at African audiences. When the Federation was dissolved in 1963, the FBC was succeeded by a new organisation responsible for broadcasting in Southern Rhodesia, known as the Rhodesian Broadcasting Corporation (RBC).[https://www.google.co.uk/search?num=30&rlz=1C1GGRV_enGB751GB751&biw=1024&bih=662&tbm=bks&q=%22The+Federal+Broadcasting+Corporation+came+into+being+on+1+February+1958%2C+and+lasted+until+the+break-up+of+the+Federation+in+December+1963%22&oq=%22The+Federal+Broadcasting+Corporation+came+into+being+on+1+February+1958%2C+and+lasted+until+the+break-up+of+the+Federation+in+December+1963%22&gs_l=psy-ab.3...11921.17478.0.18329.2.2.0.0.0.0.0.0..0.0.dummy_maps_web_fallback...0...1.1.64.psy-ab..2.0.0....0.us36OBUNwz0 ''Handbook of the Commonwealth Broadcasting Association''], Commonwealth Broadcasting Association, 1988, page 142 ===Introduction of television=== [[Television]] was introduced on 14 November 1960, first in [[Harare|Salisbury]], with transmissions in [[Bulawayo]] beginning seven months later.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5sZBAQAAIAAJ&dq=rhodesia+television+rtv+1960&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=welensky ''EBU Review: Programmes, Administration, Law, Volume 71''], Administrative Office of the European Broadcasting Union, 1962, page 12 It was only the second such service in sub-Saharan Africa after Nigeria,[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xQBbVfPukGMC&pg=PA32&lpg=PA32&dq=rtv+rhodesia&source=bl&ots=26f1qRRMdU&sig=1yTPAweyK_qpt8hnFGDMLsW4nM0&hl=en&sa=X&ei=zjoYVcHYCcfYPeW1gZgC&ved=0CFkQ6AEwCw#v=onepage&q=rtv%20rhodesia&f=true ''Zimbabwe's Cinematic Arts: Language, Power, Identity''], Katrina Daly Thompson, Indiana University Press, 2013, page 32 and the first such service in southern Africa, as [[South Africa]] did not [[Television in South Africa#Opposition to introduction|introduce television]] until 1976.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ZVt0AAAAMAAJ&dq=south+africa+TV+1976+rhodesia&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Without+television+until+1976%22 ''Sanctions: The Case of Rhodesia''], Harry R. Strack, Syracuse University Press, 1978, page 235 It was initially operated by a private company, Rhodesian Television (RTV) on behalf of the then FBC, with its major shareholders being [[South Africa]]n companies, including the [[Cape Argus|Argus Group]] of newspapers, parent company of the ''[[Rhodesia Herald]]'',[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=B2Jp-k0WVWAC&lpg=PA343&vq=Argus&pg=PA45#v=onepage&q=Argus&f=true ''Against the Grain: Memoirs of a Zimbabwean Newsman''], Geoffrey Nyarota, Zebra, 2006, page 45 and Davenport and Meyer,[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HrXVAAAAMAAJ&dq=rhodesia+television+rtv&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22rhodesian+television%22+ ''Viewing the Foreign and the Local in Zimbabwe: Film, Television, and the Shona Viewers''], Katrina Daly Thompson University of Wisconsin--Madison, 2004, page 125 the latter of which operated [[LM Radio]], based in [[Mozambique]], then under [[Portuguese Mozambique|Portuguese rule]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=G2dmAAAAMAAJ&q=%22davenport+and+meyer%22+lm+radio&dq=%22davenport+and+meyer%22+lm+radio&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiM-JPHwfPKAhXlQpoKHYGHD7oQ6AEIIDAA ''Who's who of Southern Africa, Volume 54''], Ken Donaldson (Pty.) Limited, 1967, page 393 RTV was taken over by the government,[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=yjq1owYBF_kC&lpg=PA15&dq=rtv%20rhodesia&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q=rtv%20rhodesia&f=false ''Media, Public Discourse and Political Contestation in Zimbabwe''], Henning Melber, Nordic Africa Institute, 2004, page 15 with the RBC initially acquired a 51 per cent stake in the service, which became part of the RBC in 1976.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=B0gYVaPOBo_3av2bgqgM&id=T7MsAAAAMAAJ&dq=rtv+rhodesia+south+africa+sabc+1976&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=actual+part ''Broadcasting: An Introduction''], John R. Bittner, Prentice-Hall International, 1980, page 263 RBC TV was funded by advertising and a [[television licence fee]].[https://www.google.co.uk/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22RBC%27s+financial+support+comes+from+receiver+license+fees+and+advertising+revenue%22 ''Broadcasting in Africa: A Continental Survey of Radio and Television''], Sydney W. Head, Temple University Press, 1974, page 131 Television reception was confined mainly to the large cities, and most viewers were [[Whites in Zimbabwe|whites]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=G8cnAQAAIAAJ&q=rtv+rhodesia&dq=rtv+rhodesia&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjl756a39HWAhWFL1AKHUQRAZYQ6AEILjAB''Censorship''], Volume 1, Congress for Cultural Freedom., 1964, page 29 Umtali (now [[Mutare]]) only received television in 1972, by which time it was estimated that more than 90 per cent of the white population had access to the service. ===Unilateral Declaration of Independence=== In 1965, the white minority government of [[Ian Smith]] issued a [[Unilateral Declaration of Independence (Rhodesia)|Unilateral Declaration of Independence]], under which censorship of broadcasting and the press was imposed, and key posts at the RBC were gradually filled by supporters of the ruling [[Rhodesian Front]] party.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=gDqsCQAAQBAJ&lpg=PA2713&dq=%22Rhodesian%20Broadcasting%20Corporation%22%20%22Director%20General%22&pg=PA2713#v=onepage&q=%22Rhodesian%20Broadcasting%20Corporation%22%20%22Director%20General%22&f=false ''Censorship: A World Encyclopedia''], Derek Jones, Routledge, 2001, page 2713 The previous year, the Deputy Minister of Information, [[P. K. van der Byl]], described the aims of his Ministry as "not merely to disseminate information from an interesting point of view but to play its part in fighting the propaganda battle on behalf of the country".[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9jV1AAAAMAAJ&q=%22not+merely+to+disseminate+information+from+an+interesting+point+of+view+but+to+play+its+part+in+fighting+the+propaganda+battle+on+behalf+of+the+country%22&dq=%22not+merely+to+disseminate+information+from+an+interesting+point+of+view+but+to+play+its+part+in+fighting+the+propaganda+battle+on+behalf+of+the+country%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjUz7KTxq_MAhUkJcAKHW-UDj4Q6AEIHTAA ''Rhodesia: The Road to Rebellion''], James P. Barber, Institute of Race Relations, 1967, page 293 In response, the RBC Director General, James Neill, resigned, citing political interference.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=mXsjAQAAMAAJ&q=%22Rhodesian+Broadcasting+Corporation%22+%22Director+General%22&dq=%22Rhodesian+Broadcasting+Corporation%22+%22Director+General%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjK2p3xgtPWAhWLChoKHbZOCBoQ6AEIKDAA ''Combroad''], Issues 50-57, Commonwealth Broadcasting Association, 1981, page 60 On 1 January 1965, the RBC had ceased to relay the morning world news bulletin from the [[BBC]], and replaced it with a bulletin from the [[South African Broadcasting Corporation]] (SABC).[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=dMgHAQAAIAAJ&dq=%22RBC%22+%22Rhodesia%22+%22BBC%22+%22SABC%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22In+fact%2C+the+morning+world+news+bulletin%2C+previously+relayed+from+the+BBC%2C+was+replaced+with+an+SABC+broadcast%22 ''The Journalist''], 1981, page 45 However, afternoon and evening news relays of the BBC remained unchanged.[https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=On+1+January,+the+R.B.C.+discontinued+the+8+a.m.+news+relay+from+the+B.B.C.,+but+left+the+1+p.m.+and+6+p.m.+relays.+The+8+a.m.+relay+was+to+be+replaced+by+S.A.B.C.+news+relayed+from+Radio+South+Africa&num=30&rlz=1C1GGRV_enGB751GB751&source=lnms&tbm=bks&biw=1024&bih=662 ''News Letter''], Institute of Race Relations, London, 1965, page 23 The British government, which had denounced UDI as illegal, began broadcasting BBC programmes into Rhodesia by building a radio relay station in [[Francistown]], in the then [[Bechuanaland Protectorate]], now [[Botswana]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=8bg8jQxkSTcC&lpg=PA111&dq=bbc%20rhodesia%20francistown&pg=PA111#v=onepage&q=bbc%20rhodesia%20francistown&f=false ''Botswana's Search for Autonomy in Southern Africa''], Richard Dale, Greenwood Publishing Group, 1995, page 111 The Rhodesian government retaliated by clandestinely building a 400 000 watt transmitter nicknamed "Big Bertha", in order to jam the signal from the smaller BBC transmitter.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=h89JAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Big+Bertha%22+Francistown&dq=%22Big+Bertha%22+Francistown&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjT2JGrj9PWAhVB1xoKHYZ6CTcQ6AEIKDAA ''Africa Today''], Volume 31, Africa Today Associates, 1984, page 46 Programmes about Rhodesia were subjected to jamming, but other programmes were not affected.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0X_uILApgL0C&lpg=PA19&dq=bbc%20rhodesia%20francistown&pg=PA19#v=onepage&q=bbc%20rhodesia%20francistown&f=false ''Radio and Television Broadcasting on the European Continent''], Burton Paulu, University of Minnesota Press, 1967, page 19 In 1968, the BBC ceased broadcasting from Francistown, and the relay station was transferred to the government of Botswana.[https://www.google.co.uk/search?tbm=bks&hl=en&q=%22BBC+closed+down+the+transmitter+and+handed+it+over+to+the+Botswana+government+in+1968%22 ''The Politics of International Telecommunications Regulation''], James G. Savage, Westview Press, 1989, page 134 The RBC operated two main services, the English-language General Service (or National Network),[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=633bAAAAMAAJ&q=%22Radio+Rhodesia%22&dq=%22Radio+Rhodesia%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjAztzbsNPWAhUKVRoKHZ3qBOEQ6AEIMTAC ''World Radio & TV Handbook''], Oluf Lund-Johansen, Cardfont Publishers under license from Billboard Publications., 1973, aimed at the white audience, and the African Service, broadcasting in English, Shona and Ndebele, aimed at black listeners. The RBC also established three community stations with a multi-racial audience, Radio Jacaranda (Salisbury), Radio Matopos (Bulawayo) and Radio Manica (Umtali).[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=pLx1AAAAMAAJ&q=%22Radio+Jacaranda%22+%22RBC%22&dq=%22Radio+Jacaranda%22+%22RBC%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiz_5CzrdPWAhVK1BoKHfkDDxMQ6AEIKDAA ''Black List: The Concise and Comprehensive Reference Guide to Black Journalism, Radio, and Television, Educational and Cultural Organizations in the USA, Africa, and the Caribbean''], Volume 2, Black List, 1975, page 286 In 1975, an [[Ndebele language (Zimbabwe)|Ndebele language]] service operating out of [[Bulawayo]], known as Radio Mthwakazi, was established, using the "Big Bertha" transmitter previously used to jam the BBC's broadcasts from Francistown.[https://www.google.co.uk/search?q=One+example+of+this+divide-and-rule+focus+in+broadcasting+was+the+setting+up+of+an+%27Ndebele+station%27+(Radio+Mthwakazi)+in+the+Bulawayo+area+in+1975,+utilizing+the+powerful+%27Big+Bertha%27+transmitter,+which+had+previously+been+used+to+jam+the&num=30&rlz=1C1GGRV_enGB751GB751&source=lnms&tbm=bks&biw=1024&bih=662 ''Broadcasting and Political Change in Zimbabwe 1931-1984''], James Joseph Zaffiro - 1984, page 74 As armed opposition to white minority rule mounted in the 1970s, Africans in Rhodesia increasingly began to turn to [[short wave]] radio broadcasts from neighbouring countries, which carried programmes from exiled nationalist movements, with the [[Zimbabwe African National Union (Patriotic Front)|Zimbabwe African National Union]]'s Voice of Zimbabwe operating from [[Mozambique]], and the rival [[Zimbabwe African People's Union]]'s Voice of the Revolution operating from [[Zambia]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=uLenDhrLQ8oC&lpg=PA15&ots=3LG9ihNew5&dq=Zimbabwe%20African%20People's%20Union's%20Voice%20of%20the%20Revolution%20operating%20from%20Zambia.&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q=Zimbabwe%20African%20People's%20Union's%20Voice%20of%20the%20Revolution%20operating%20from%20Zambia.&f=false ''Making sense of cultural nationalism and the politics of commemoration under the Third Chimurenga in Zimbabwe''], Sabelo J. Ndlovu-Gatsheni and Wendy Willems, ''Journal of Southern African Studies'', 35 (4). pp. 945-965 In order to counter this, the RBC installed an [[FM broadcasting|FM]] network, while the government distributed FM-only receivers to chiefs and village headmen in the Tribal Trust Lands. It also ran campaigns promoting FM-only receivers, pointing out that they were exempt from the annual [[licence fee]], and how short wave broadcasts were affected by [[noise (radio)|static noise]] and required retuning between frequencies throughout the day.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=kpmyAAAAIAAJ&q=%22rhodesian+broadcasting+corporation%22+%22licence+fee%22&dq=%22rhodesian+broadcasting+corporation%22+%22licence+fee%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiN04PtgNPWAhXC1hoKHRqCD9sQ6AEIKDAA ''International Journal''], Volume 42, Canadian Institute of International Affairs, 1987, page 346 ===Transition to independence=== In [[1979]], following the adoption of a new constitution, Rhodesia was renamed [[Zimbabwe Rhodesia]], and in common with other state institutions which were renamed, the state broadcaster was renamed the Zimbabwe Rhodesia Broadcasting Corporation (ZRBC) or the Voice of Zimbabwe Rhodesia (VZR).[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AsZNAAAAYAAJ&q=%22Voice+of+Zimbabwe+Rhodesia%22&dq=%22Voice+of+Zimbabwe+Rhodesia%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwijze6U5NLWAhVL1hoKHcoPD7oQ6AEILTAB ''World Radio TV Handbook''], Billboard Publications, 1980, page 185 This also saw the debut of Mandy Mundawarara, the country's first black television newsreader, whose father, Silas Mundawarara, had become Deputy Prime Minister in the government of [[Abel Muzorewa]]. However, the Muzorewa government did not gain international recognition, and under the terms of the [[Lancaster House Agreement]], the country officially reverted to British rule as "Southern Rhodesia", with [[Christopher Soames, Baron Soames|Lord Soames]] as [[Governor of Southern Rhodesia|Governor]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=rTDvVo52tEAC&lpg=PA91&ots=RBUrvvu_Sa&dq=%22Constitution%20of%20Zimbabwe%20Rhodesia%22&pg=PA91#v=onepage&q=%22Constitution%20of%20Zimbabwe%20Rhodesia%22&f=true ''Collective Responses to Illegal Acts in International Law: United Nations Action in the Question of Southern Rhodesia''], Vera Gowlland-Debbas Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, 1990, page 91 Despite this, the Corporation's name remained unchanged.[http://hansard.millbanksystems.com/lords/1979/dec/17/zimbabwe-bill-1#S5LV0403P0_19791217_HOL_102 ZIMBABWE BILL], HL Deb 17 December 1979 vol 403 cc1470-514 A number of other senior BBC staff were sent to the country to advise Lord Soames on election broadcasting, and also help the ZRBC with their preparations for independence.[https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/obituaries/1394002/Austen-Kark.html Obituary: Austen Kark], ''[[Daily Telegraph]]'', 13 May 2002 In the run-up to elections being held in February 1980, the Governor's Information Adviser held discussions with the ZRBC, leading the Election Commissioner agreed to a scheme to ensure that all parties standing in the elections should have equal free time on the public media.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=jVENAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Zimbabwe+Rhodesia+Broadcasting+Corporation%22&dq=%22Zimbabwe+Rhodesia+Broadcasting+Corporation%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiLjYrk5dLWAhWHNhoKHdZSBVIQ6AEIWjAK Southern Rhodesia: Independence Elections 1980: Report of the Election Commissioner Sir John Boynton, MC, Salisbury, March 1980], John K. Boynton, Great Britain. Foreign and Commonwealth Office, Her Majesty's Stationery Office, 1980, page 31 ==Post-independence== ===Establishment of ZBC=== Following independence, the state broadcaster became the Zimbabwe Broadcasting Corporation (ZBC).[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=HqpAAQAAIAAJ&q=%22Rhodesia+Broadcasting+Corporation+has+become+Zimbabwe+Broadcasting+Corporation%22&dq=%22Rhodesia+Broadcasting+Corporation+has+become+Zimbabwe+Broadcasting+Corporation%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj__er13NHWAhUGElAKHUHVB2EQ6AEIKDAA ''EBU Review: Radio and television programmes, administration, law''], Volume 31, Administrative Office of the European Broadcasting Union, 1980, page 62 In a reflection of the news [[ZANU PF]] government's political leanings, [[Robert Mugabe]], previously described only as "a terrorist leader", was now described as "[[Prime Minister of Zimbabwe|Comrade Prime Minister]]".[https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/politics/1980/06/01/zimbabwes-news-media-change-tune-under-black-rule/b67c6c36-b778-41c0-8db2-db1b61b30b7d/ Zimbabwe's News Media Change Tune Under Black Rule], ''[[Washington Post]]'', June 1, 1980 In addition, most of the white staff left ZBC after independence, and many of the black staff who replaced them had previously worked in for radio services operated by the nationalist movements from exile in [[Zambia]] and [[Mozambique]].[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=TMX3_raXHDcC&lpg=PA143&dq=zbc%20monopoly%201997&pg=PA143#v=onepage&q&f=false The dual legacy of democracy and authoritarianism], Helge Ronning and Tawana Kupe, in ''[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=TMX3_raXHDcC&lpg=PA143&dq=zbc%20monopoly%201997&pg=PA138#v=onepage&q&f=false De-Westernizing Media Studies]'', editors James Curran, Myung-Jin Park, Routledge, 5 Jul 2005, page 138 Radio services were reorganised, with three distinct networks being established: Radio One, the main English-language network, run by Africans but with some whites in key positions, Radio Two, combining the Harare and Radio Mthwakazi services and broadcasting in [[Shona language|Shona]] and [[Ndebele language (Zimbabwe)|Ndebele]], and Radio Three, replacing Radio Jacaranda.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=-SMoAQAAMAAJ&q=Radio+Mthwakazi&dq=Radio+Mthwakazi&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj4ovnCktPWAhXJmBoKHd-EAAMQ6AEITjAI ''Proceedings of the African Women's Features Services Workshop, Marandellas, Zimbabwe, 12-23 October, 1981''], UNESCO Regional Population Communication Unit for Africa, page 60 Radio Four was established in 1982, as an educational channel. The legacy of [[Unilateral Declaration of Independence (Rhodesia)#British and international responses; sanctions|economic sanctions]] meant that ZBC inherited antiquated equipment with spares difficult to obtain, as manufacturers no longer produced [[black and white television]] transmission equipment.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=n4i2AAAAIAAJ&dq=%22Zimbabwe%22+%22TV%22++%22black+and+white%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22black+and+white+TV+transmission+equipment%22 ''Zimbabwe- The First Decade''], Elias Rusike, Roblaw Publishers, 1990, page 54 In addition, the television service, now known as ZTV, only reached only 32 percent of the country's territory.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=proWAQAAMAAJ&q=%22ZTV+is+composed+of+one+black-and-white+TV+channel+which+covers+32+percent+of+the+country%27s+territory%22&dq=%22ZTV+is+composed+of+one+black-and-white+TV+channel+which+covers+32+percent+of+the+country%27s+territory%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjEubvb0tHWAhVCZlAKHeXuBWIQ6AEIKDAA ''Country Market Survey''], Department of Commerce, Industry and Trade Administration., 1982, page 6 The conversion to [[colour television]] began in late 1982, using the [[PAL#PAL-B/G/D/K/I|PAL B]] system.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=b0kNAQAAMAAJ&q=%22conversion+of+the+black+and+white+television+service+to+colour+on+the+PAL+B+System%22&dq=%22conversion+of+the+black+and+white+television+service+to+colour+on+the+PAL+B+System%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjEmL7z1tHWAhXRY1AKHWm2DakQ6AEIKDAA ''International TV & Video Guide''], Tantivy Press, 1985, page 204 Colour transmissions were finally introduced in 1984.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?ei=nEsYVfK3MtbWavGogpAO&id=2MhBAAAAYAAJ&dq=zbc+tv+colour+1984&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Colour+transmission ''A Concise Encyclopedia of Zimbabwe''], Donatus Bonde, Mambo Press, 1988, page 410 As much of the machinery had been in used for over two decades, and was now obsolete, it proved more economical to buy entirely new equipment than to replace it.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=6xwxAQAAIAAJ&q=%22the+old+black-and-white+machinery%22&dq=%22the+old+black-and-white+machinery%22&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiC-Miq1NHWAhVFmbQKHcK2ANIQ6AEIKDAA ''Africa Calls from Zimbabwe''], Issues 131-138, Africa Calls Publishers, 1982, page 22 A second television channel, available only in [[Harare]],[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rkm7AAAAIAAJ&dq=%22Zimbabwe+Broadcasting+Corporation%22+%22second%22+%22TV%22+%22channel%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Harare+area%22 ''Children and Women in Zimbabwe: A Situation Analysis, Update 1994''], Unicef, 1994, page 40 was introduced in 1986.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=pDwIAQAAMAAJ&dq=%22Zimbabwe+Broadcasting+Corporation%22+%22second%22+%22TV%22+%22channel%22+%221986%22&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22In+1986%2C+ZBC+installed+a+second+channel%22 ''Africa Film & TV''], Z Promotions, 2001, page 217 ===Local programming=== At independence, 30 per cent of television programming was locally produced.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=xQBbVfPukGMC&lpg=PA51&dq=zbc%20tv%20programme%20imports%2030%20per%20cent%20local&pg=PA51#v=onepage&q=zbc%20tv%20programme%20imports%2030%20per%20cent%20local&f=false ''Zimbabwe's Cinematic Arts: Language, Power, Identity''], Katrina Daly Thompson, Indiana University Press, 2013, page 51 By late 1982, local programmes accounted for 40 per cent of output.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=AiAoAQAAMAAJ&q=%22colour+television%22+ZBC&dq=%22colour+television%22+ZBC&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjmleip69TWAhUSalAKHbZ1BkIQ6AEIRjAH ''Report of Second Meeting of Monitoring Group on Follow-up to Intergovernmental Conference on Communication Policies in Africa: Harare, Zimbabwe, 26-29 October 1982''], AFRICOM Monitoring Group. Meeting, United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, 1982, page 9 While some programming was in Shona and Ndebele, 80 per cent of programming was in English, of which most was imported, mainly from the US, Britain and Australia.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rkm7AAAAIAAJ&dq=zbc+tv+programme+imports+africa&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=%22Most+of+these%2C+except+for+news+and+current+affairs+programmes%2C+are+imported+British%2C+Australian%2C+or+American+shows%22 ''Children and Women in Zimbabwe: A Situation Analysis, Update 1994''], Unicef 1994, page 41 Despite this reliance on foreign content, in the 1980s, the locally produced drama ''The Mukadota Family'' became the most popular programme in the country.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=0KIR8RucnDYC&lpg=PA41&dq=mukadota%20family&pg=PA41#v=onepage&q=mukadota%20family&f=false ''How "American" Is Globalization?''], William Marling, JHU Press, 2006, page 41 As the 1957 Broadcasting Act remained in force, ZBC inherited RBC's state monopoly on broadcasting, remaining accountable to the country's Minister of Information.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=uRZDAQAAIAAJ&q=zbc+monopoly+broadcasting+act+1957&dq=zbc+monopoly+broadcasting+act+1957&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjExo3r7tXWAhWLmbQKHetqD6IQ6AEIQzAF ''Media, democracy and development''], Elin W. Andersen, Dept. of Media and Communication, University of Oslo, 1997, page 10 Expressing his dislike of independent broadcasting in 1995, [[Robert Mugabe]], by now [[President of Zimbabwe|President]], remarked "you do not know what propaganda a non-state radio station might broadcast".[https://www.google.co.uk/search?num=30&hl=en&tbm=bks&ei=39r6W47zNsyBgAbzy4vQAQ&q=%22you+do+not+know+what+propaganda+a+non-state+radio+station+might+broadcast%22&oq=%22you+do+not+know+what+propaganda+a+non-state+radio+station+might+broadcast%22&gs_l=psy-ab.3...9458.9458.0.10088.1.1.0.0.0.0.85.85.1.1.0....0...1c.1.64.psy-ab..0.0.0....0.aeErTgLYx3I ''Critical Analysis of the Media Law in Zimbabwe''], Nkosi Ndlela, Media Institute of Southern Africa. Zimbabwe Chapter, Konrad Adenauer Foundation, 2003, page 44 However, the [[Government of Zimbabwe|government]] announced that the ZBC monopoly on broadcasting would be abolished by the end of 1997.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9PcEULjohrUC&lpg=PA396&ots=NZTm-75_hY&dq=zbc%20monopoly&pg=PA396#v=onepage&q=zbc%20monopoly&f=false Zimbabwe], Øyvind Thiis and Geoff Feltoe, in [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9PcEULjohrUC&dq=zbc+monopoly&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''International Human Rights in Developing Countries Yearbook 1997''], editors Hugo Stokke, Astri Suhrke, Arne Tostensen, Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, 1998, page 396 As a result, the ZBC's second TV channel was discontinued and replaced by Joy TV, the country's first independent channel, which operated on a lease agreement with the ZBC.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=ypFWqOJFKPEC&pg=PA58&lpg=PA58&dq=joy+tv+zimbabwe&source=bl&ots=fX0tP1X4ZL&sig=m7JorC7v1hYI5bUA0C9YoBmKyXY&hl=en&sa=X&ei=0k4YVfvUHIGtPZiGgLAH&ved=0CG0Q6AEwDQ#v=onepage&q=joy%20tv%20zimbabwe&f=true ''Culture and Customs of Zimbabwe''], Oyekan Owomoyela, Greenwood Publishing Group, 2002, page 58 This channel lasted until 2002, when it was controversially taken off the air for allegedly violating the Broadcasting Services Act.[http://www.pambazuka.net/en/category.php/media/8085 Zimbabwe: CURTAIN COMES DOWN ON JOY TV], ''Pambazuka'', 6 June 2001 ===Accusations of pro-government bias=== In 2015, [[Freedom House]] described ZBC coverage as overwhelmingly favouring the ruling [[ZANU-PF]].[https://freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-press/2016/zimbabwe Zimbabwe Freedom of the Press], [[Freedom House]], 2016 In 2003, a study conducted by the Media Monitoring Project of Zimbabwe (MMPZ) in 2003 showed that one of the propaganda jingles, ''Rambai Makashinga'' or "Continue Persevering", was being played 288 times a day on the four ZBC radio stations, and 72 times a day on ZBC television.[https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=LJbFniZhtDQC&lpg=PA81&dq=Zimbabwe%20Broadcasting%20Corporation%20censorship&pg=PA81#v=onepage&q=Zimbabwe%20Broadcasting%20Corporation%20censorship&f=false ''Zimbabwe: A Survey''], African Minds, 2009, page 81 ==Radio== The ZBC has five radio networks, which are ZBC National FM, broadcasting news and current affairs in [[English language|English]],[http://www.nationalfm.co.zw/ National FM] ZBC Radio Zimbabwe broadcasts programming in [[Shona language|Shona]] and [[Northern Ndebele language|Ndebele]],[http://www.radiozim.co.zw/ Radio Zimbabwe] Power FM, broadcasting pop music,[http://www.powerfm.co.zw/ Power FM], Classic 263 (formerly Sport FM) carrying sports news.[http://www.sfm.co.zw/ SFM] and the [[Bulawayo]] based Khulumani FM, broadcasting is languages that are mainly spoke in the Matabeleland Region. Local radio stations run hourly news bulletins which range from two minutes to the longest being a ten-minute bulletin on weekends and holidays. Presenters include, Admire Mhungu, Innocent Manyenga, Memory Chamisa and Keith Mawoyo. On the national languages desk readers include Nqobile Malinga, Patience Machokoto, Taboka Ncube, Faith Nare, Lucy Ngosolo and Caroline Sithole. Bulletins come out live on SFM at 7 am, 8 am, 1 pm, 6 pm and 8 pm and running from Monday to Friday. The anchors are Nomalanga Vuma, Theophilus Chuma, Ian Zvoma, Butler Nhepure and Jonathan Marerwa. ==Television== ZBC's television service now consists of a single channel, known as ZBC TV. The ZBC re-established a second TV channel of its own, Channel 2, in April 2010,[http://allafrica.com/stories/201004130289.html Zimbabwe: ZBC to Launch Channel Two], ''[[The Herald (Zimbabwe)|The Herald]]'', 13 April 2010 but this station was decommissioned in August 2015.[https://www.dailynews.co.zw/articles/2015/08/12/zbc-fires-hundreds-closes-tv-station ZBC fires hundreds, closes TV station], ''[[Daily News (Zimbabwe)|Daily News]]'', 12 August 2015 News bulletins include the morning ''Good Morning Zimbabwe'', produced by Admire Mhungu, lunchtime news, ''Nhau Indaba'' and ''News Hour''.[http://www.zbc.co.zw/?option=com_content&view=article&id=546&Itemid=99 ZBC-TV Programme Line Up] Rumbidzai Takawira, the anchor, is usually the host of ''News Hour''. ''[[Battle Of The Chefs Harare|Battle of the Chefs]]'' is one of the first food-related reality TV shows to air on ZBC. ==See also== * [[Media of Zimbabwe]] * [[Communications in Zimbabwe]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.zbc.co.zw ZBC] [[Category:1980 establishments in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Media in Zimbabwe]] [[Category:Publicly funded broadcasters]] [[Category:Multilingual broadcasters]] [[Category:Television channels and stations established in 1980]] [[Category:Television in Zimbabwe]]
